choices.text: Uterine contraction during labor by oxytocin
Circulatory collapse in case of irreversible shock

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of a positive feedback mechanism?
questions.solution:
Negative feedback mechanism maintains the level of substances in a normal range.

Positive feedback mechanism produces change in one direction.

Option a: During pregnancy in the last trimester, oxytocin causes uterine contraction. It increases further stretch on the uterus which further increases the oxytocin secretion. This cycle goes on till baby delivery. It is a positive feedback mechanism.

Option b: When shock becomes severe and various types of positive feedback mechanisms develop, they cause a vicious cycle of progressively decreasing cardiac output and functioning. (Na+, K+, Mitochondria, Lysosome change in activity)

Option c: Baroreceptors mechanism regulates the blood pressure. When blood pressure increases, the increase in baroreceptor discharge reduces the blood pressure and vice versa. Change occurs in both directions. It is an example of a negative feedback mechanism.

Option d: Generation of action potential due to increase in activation of sodium channels is an example of positive feedback mechanism.

Tag: Feedback regulation

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page Number 93, 224, 1336.

questions.text: Identify the ion marked with an arrow
questions.solution:
• Sodium ions, chloride ions and bicarbonate levels are high in the ECF.
  • Potassium level is high in the intracellular fluid.
  • Level of sodium ions in ECF is around 142 meq/liter.

Tag: Fluid compartment

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page Number-23, fig1-1

questions.text: Among the given list, which of the following is a type of integral protein?
questions.solution:
• There are two varieties of membrane proteins.
  • One Integral proteins, which protrude all the way through the membrane
  • Two peripheral proteins, which are attached only to one surface of the membrane and do not penetrate all the way through.
  • Ion channel proteins, carrier proteins, hormone receptor proteins (G protein) are integral proteins as they protrude through both sides of membrane. Cell adhesion molecules(Option B) and Cell recognition molecules(Option C) are example of peripheral protein which is attached to only one surface.

Tag: Cell physiology

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page Number-16

questions.text: Which of the following is molecular motor?
questions.solution:
• The molecular motors are also called as Cargo of cells that move proteins, organelles, or other parts of cells.
  • They attach to their cargo at one end of the molecule and to microtubules or actin polymers with the other end, sometimes referred to as the head.
  • They use the energy from ATP to move cargo.
  • Kinesin, Dynein, Myosin are super families of molecular motors.
  • Clathrin(Option A) is a protein found on the inner cell membrane useful of endocytosis.
  • Spectrin(Option B) is a protein found on RBC membrane. It helps to maintain shape and flexibility in RBCs.
  • Microtubule is transport system of cells, on which molecular motors move the structure inside the cell.

Tag: Cell physiology

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page Number 104, 106, 124, 1265.

questions.text: 7-year-old boy, is brought to the paediatric neurology clinic by his parents due to concerns about her developmental delay. At birth he was full term and had no complications at delivery. On evaluation it is found that he had defect in Tyrosine kinase associated receptors B. Which of the following factor does not bind to Trk B receptors?
questions.solution:
• There are three high affinity tyrosine kinase receptors which bind to neurotrophins. They are Trk A, Trk B, Trk C.
  • Following are the receptors that react with the particular neurotrophins.
  • The only factor that does not react with Trk B is nerve growth factor.

Tag: Neurotrophins

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page Number-237.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male was very tired after a whole busy day. At night he went to a deep sleep with left arm under the head whole night. On next morning as he got up he has paralysis in left arm. It occurred due to compression of which fibers from the following?
questions.solution:
• The various type of a fibers react to different kind of factors (pressure , hypoxia, local anesthetics) differently.
  • Type C fibers are most susceptible to local anesthetic before it affects other type of fibers.
  • Type B fibers are most susceptible to hypoxia than other type of fibers.
  • Type A fibers are most susceptible to sustained pressure than other type of fibers.
  • As above patient was over drunk than slept. Due to deep sleep he was not aware about sleeping whole night while his hand was under his head. So constant pressure compressed his nerves. But type A fibers are most susceptible to pressure so he had paralysis (type A fibers are motor, touch and pressure fibers).

Tag: Nerve physiology

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page Number-231 table 4-3

questions.text: Among the following in the skeletal muscle cells which are voltage gated calcium channel allowing movement of calcium ions?
questions.solution:
• Dihydropyridine (DHP) receptors triggers the opening of the calcium release channels in the cisternae, as well as in their attached longitudinal tubules. This channel is activated by t tubule depolarization. It is voltage gated calcium channel.
  • SERCA (sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+-ATPase), can concentrate the calcium ions about 10,000-fold inside the tubules. As it pumps calcium ions away from the myofibrils back into the sarcoplasmic tubules. It is an active transport mechanism. (Option B)
  • Ryanodine receptor (RYR) proteins are found on terminal cisternae. The RyR is a ligand-gated Ca2+ channel with Ca2+ as its natural ligand. (Option C)
  • DHP & RYR helps in moving calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm during muscle contraction.
  • Inside the reticulum is a calcium-binding protein called calsequestrin, which can bind up to 40 calcium ions for each molecule of calsequestrin. (Option D)

Tag: Muscle physiology

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page Number-260.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female visited the primary care physician for his weakness and easy fatiguability. Doctor investigated her and found her MCV is 100 fl. The RBCs in this female is
questions.solution:
• MCV is mean corpuscular volume of RBCs. It is average volume of RBCs in blood.
  • MCV = Hct*10/ RBC (10⁶/microliter)
  • Hematocrit is percentage of RBCs in total blood.
  • Normal MCV value is aroud 90 fl.
  • If it is < 80 fl RBCs are smaller known as microcytes. IF it is >95 fl RBCs are macrocytic.
  • Macrocytic RBCs are seen in
    • Vit B12 deficiency
    • Folic acid deficiency
  • Hypochromic RBCs are seen when hemoglobin is less in RBCs. It cannot be determined by MCV.(Option D)
  • Microcytic RBCs(Option A) are seen in
    • Iron deficiency anemia
    • Thalassemia

Tag: RBCs

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page Number-1262.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy had fever and cough. He was admitted to hospital. The pediatrician examined him and sent some investigations. Patient was diagnosed with bacterial infection. Which of the following WBCs are increased in this infection?
questions.solution:
• Neutrophil are primarily functioning against bacterial infection as they phagocytose bacteria. Parasites are larger in size, so they cannot be engulfed by neutrophils.
  • Increase in neutrophil count is known as neutrophilia
  • Neutrophilia is seen in New borne babies, After exercise, After meals, Pregnancy, parturition, lactation, Mental & emotional stress, Acute pyogenic bacterial infection, Non infective inflammatory conditions ( gout, acute rheumatic fever), Burns, MI, Post operative, Acute haemorrhage, Uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Eosinophils(Option B) are abundant in the gastrointestinal tract, here they defend against parasites, and in the mucosa of the respiratory and urinary tracts. Eosinophils are increased in allergic diseases as well.
  • Basophils(Option C) are increased in allergic reactions. They release histamine and other inflammatory mediators when activated by binding of specific antigens to cell-fixed IgE molecules, and participate in immediate-type hypersensitivity (allergic) reactions.
  • Lymphocytes(Option D)are immune cells of body. They provide cell mediated and antibody mediated immunity.

Tag: WBCs

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page Number 202- 204.

choices.text: It activates the antithrombin III and acts as an anticoagulant
It lyses fibrin and fibrinogen to produce fibrin degradation products
It acts as a calcium chelating agent

questions.text: A 51-year-old patient had chest pain. He was immediately carried to emergency department. Immediate ECG finding suggest myocardial infarction. He was given Streptokinase immediately. Streptokinase acts by
questions.solution:
• Streptokinase is a bacterial enzyme obtained from bacteria.
  • It is potent fibrinolytic enzyme, a potent tissue plasminogen activator.
  • It acts via following mechanism
  • Heparin is a naturally occurring anticoagulant that facilitates the action of antithrombin III.(Option A)
  • Chelating agents bind with the calcium and prevents clotting mechanism (dicumarol)(Option C)

Tag: Hemostasis

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page Number 1287-1288.

choices.text: Galactose is obtained from lactose in the body
Reaction of UDPG (uridine diphosphoglucose) with glucose forms uridine diphosphogalactose
The utilization of galactose is dependent on insulin
Congenital deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase produces galactosemia

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Galactose metabolism?
questions.solution:
Apart from glucose other hexoses are also metabolized in the body.

Digestion lactose forms glucose and galactose

The utilization of galactose same as glucose depends on insulin

Galactose 1 phosphate reacts with UDPG to form uridine diphosphogalactose with the use of enzyme

galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase.

Congenital deficiency of above-mentioned enzyme causes accumulation of galactose in the blood called It is an inborn error of metabolism. Serous disturbances in growth and development occurs dueto galactosemia.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 73-74

questions.text: It is not true about which of the following is a subunit of ion channel?
questions.solution:
• The K+ channel has only a single repeat of the six spanning regions and P loop. It is tetramer having four subunits.
  • The Na+ channel and Ca++ channel have 4 repeats of each of above diagram. The α subunit of the Na+ and Ca2+ channels traverses the
    • membrane 24 times in four repeats of six membrane-spanning units.
  • Each repeat has a "P" loop between membrane spans 5 and 6 that does not traverse the membrane. P loop is thought to form pore.
  • span 4 of each repeat is coloured in red, representing its net "+" charge.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number:132 fig 2-7

questions.text: A 43-year-old has weakness in the muscles. He visited the physician. On examination he has muscle atrophy also. On evaluation doctor found that patient has metabolic myopathy. Correct diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• McArdle syndrome, or glycogen storage disease type V, is a metabolic myopathy caused by a deficiency of muscle phosphorylase, an enzyme involved in glycogen breakdown.
  • This deficiency impairs the muscle's ability to utilize glycogen for energy, leading to muscle weakness, cramping, and atrophy.
  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by the absence of dystrophin, leading to progressive muscle weakness and atrophy(Option A).
  • It typically presents in early childhood.
  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder affecting the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness and fatigue.
  • It is not a metabolic myopathy; rather, it involves antibodies blocking or destroying acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.(Option B)
  • Tibialis muscular dystrophy is a genetic muscle disease of titin that is predicted to destabilize the folded state of the protein(Option D)

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 252

questions.text: The skeletal muscle fibers with high oxidative capacity and resistant to fatigue, small in diameter are
questions.solution:
• Type I muscle fibers, also known as slow-twitch or slow oxidative fibers, are characterized by small diameter, high oxidative capacity, resistance to fatigue. High density of mitochondria and myoglobin, which support sustained aerobic (oxygen-dependent) activities.
  • Type II A fibers(Option B), also known as fast-twitch oxidative fibers, are intermediate in nature. Characteristic are
    • Moderate oxidative capacity
    • Large diameter
    • Less resistant to fatigue than type I
    • Useful in middle-distance running
  • Type II B fibers(Option C), also known as fast-twitch glycolytic fibers, are characterized by their large diameter, high glycolytic capacity, lower oxidative capacity suitable for activities such as sprinting or heavy lifting.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 269 Table 5-2

questions.text:
A 39-year-old patient has the following hematological values:

Hemoglobin (Hb): 10 g/dL
Hematocrit (Hct): 36%
Red Blood Cell (RBC) count: 4.0 million/μL

What is the Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) is calculated using the following formula:
    • MCHC =Hemoglobin (Hb) divided by Hematocrit (Hct) × 100
    • Hemoglobin (Hb) is measured in g/dL =12 g/dl
    • Hematocrit (Hct) is expressed as a percentage (i.e., Hct should be converted to a decimal by dividing by 100).
    • Hematocrit in decimal is 0.36 (36%)
  • MCHC = 10*100/0.36
  • It is 27.77 g/dl
  • MCHC is an important parameter to diagnose iron deficiency anemia if it is less than 25 g/dl it is hypochromic anemia.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1262 Table 31-2
